reviewText: We have the first three episodes and they are great. But I wish Amazon would warn you that already have one of the videos before you purchase it again. We had bought the Budapest video in it's single season and it was the same one here. So I paid for it twice. This of course is not Rick Steves fault and folks should just beware. However the Prague video I think is different. All are great overviews of the areas covered.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Has there ever been another travel guide more amiable, more informative, more eclectic and just plain likeable than Rick Steves?  This somewhat nerdish but pleasant looking fellow will immediately win the viewer over with his charm, humor and smoothing, layback manner. However what will keep you watching program after program is his consummate knowledge of the sites and people he visits.While each journey is only 30 minutes in length Rick has a unique talent of synthesizing the many facets that make up a people and place. He leaves no stone unturned in his analysis; historical background, spiritual heritage, cultural underpinnings and political legacy are all equally touched upon to give the audience a fuller understanding of the rural and urban landscape.However not not an individual to dwell too much on the past, he provides a delightful tour of the markets, music, restaurants and nightlife. The kind of information would really want to know if you're out for a good time.The production values are also wonderful offering fanstastic visuals that are worth watching even if there where no commentary. Traveling with Rick Steves' is the next best thing to being there.This particular DVD contains five episodes, thirty minutes in length. Enjoy two and one half hours traveling through Poland, Hungary, Slovenia, Croatia, Bulgaria and the Czech Republic, better get started!
summary: "Hi, I'm Rick Steves'" ~ Traveling Through Eastern Europe From The Comfort Of Home
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rick Steves never disappoints when taking you through the most interesting sights of any country. Beautifully filmed, this adventure leaves you wanting to go touring along with Rick! He takes you to some of the most famous places, but also shows some little known gems that make trips special.I watch these films with my children, after which we fantasize which places we would go if given the chance! Good, clean fun!!
summary: A Fun Way to Live Vicariously!

reviewText: Having been to some of the locations shown on this Rick Steves travel DVD, it was very enjoyable to see some of the features once again. These DVDs are broken down into 30 minute segments that make viewing them events that are refreshing and not tedious. We have several of these travel DVDs and really enjoy the visual travelog format.

reviewText: you just can:t beat the way Rick travels to different lands it is great fun and for me wonderful memories of past travels.

reviewText: Over the course of watching numerous travel and adventure shows, I've become exceedingly aware of (and weary of) the egotistical host/hostess that takes focus away from the region or subject that they are presenting.  How many times do we need to see a hostess, wearing a provocative dress, walk in slow motion and alone across the threshold of some major tourist attraction?  Or what about the hackneyed close up of some handsome host starring into the distance, pretending to pontificate about some metaphysical mystery as the sun sets on some natural wonder?  And, of course, there's always the embarrassing host that thinks he/she's a comedian...Phooey!!Rick Steves definitely isn't hip; sometimes he's downright nerdy and milquetoasty...And he looks like he could be your nondescript suburban neighbor mowing his lawn.  However, when it comes to reverence for travel and historical focus, he is the gold standard for travel television. His informed, yet unassuming, approach feels much more sincere than many of the "personalities" that jockey for position amongst the travel shows.  His focus is always about the sites, the culture and history, and the people of the regions that he visits. With so many hosts today that like to have their big, ego-inflated, mellonheads constantly in front of the camera, it's truly refreshing to watch someone who understands that most people watch travel shows for travel tips, education, and beautiful cinematography - not for some hammy twit trying to make a name for himself or herself!In this 6 episode set, Rick Steves travels to Poland (Krakow, Auschwitz, & Warsaw), Prague (& the Czech Republic), Slovenia, Croatia, Budapest, Bulgaria, and Eastern Turkey.  All of the episodes are intriguing and filled with a vast wealth of information.  However, due to the fact that I knew so little about Slovenia, Croatia, and Bulgaria, I found these segments to be particularly interesting - Specifically, I found the Croatian cities of Dubrovnik and Split to be amazingly picturesque and stunning; one day I hope to see them in person.
summary: Rick Steves - the gold standard for travel television
